input: Faye and her mom were picking carrots from their garden. Faye picked 23 and her mother picked 5. If only 12 of the carrots were good, how many bad carrots did they have?
output: Faye picked 23 and her mother picked 5. This means Faye picked 23 - 5 = 18 carrots and her mother picked 5 - 18 = 13 carrots. So in total they picked 18 + 13 = 31 carrots. Of these, 12 were good. So the number of bad carrots must be 31 - 12 = 19. The answer is 19.

input: At the schools book fair Sam bought 13 adventure books and 17 mystery books. If 15 of the books were used, how many new books did he buy?
output: The books Sam bought were 13 adventure books and 17 mystery books. If 15 of the books were used, then the remaining books must be the 13 adventure books. So, the answer is 17 mystery books.

input: Amy had 26 music files and 36 video files on her flash drive. If she deleted 48 of the files, how many files were still on her flash drive?
output: She had 26 music files and 36 video files on her flash drive. If she deleted 48 of the files, then she deleted 48 music files and 36 video files. She is left with 0 music files and 36 video files. The answer is 36.

input: Emily was playing a trivia game. In the first round she scored 16 points and in the second round she scored 33 points. In the last round she lost 48 points. How many points did she have at the end of the game?
output: She lost 48 points in the last round. This means she had 16 + 33 - 48 = 16 + 33 - 48 = 47 points in the last round. She scored 16 points in the first round, so in the last round she has 47 - 16 = 31 points. The answer is 31.

input: Paige had 43 math problems and 12 science problems for homework. If she finished 44 of the problems at school, how many problems did she have to do for homework?
output: She finished 44 problems at school. She had 43 math problems and 12 science problems, so that means she had 43 + 12 = 55 problems for homework. The answer is 55.

input: Janet picked 4 tulips and 11 roses to make flower bouquets. If she only used 11 of the flowers though, how many extra flowers did Janet pick?
output: She picked 4 tulips and 11 roses. She used 11 of them. That means she has 4 - 11 = -7 tulips left. She picked 4 tulips and -7 tulips. She picked 4 + (-7) = 4 tulips extra. The answer is 4. input: Edward started his own lawn mowing business. In the spring he made 2 dollars mowing lawns and in the summer he made 27 dollars. If he had to spend 5 dollars buying supplies, how much money did he end up with?
output: In the spring he made 2 dollars, but he had to spend 5 dollars on supplies. This means he made 2 - 5 = -3 dollars in the spring. In the summer he made 27 - 5 = 22 dollars. If he adds both, he ends up with -3 + 22 = 19 dollars. The answer is 19.

input: For the school bake sale Amy made pastries. She baked 15 cupcakes and 48 cookies. After the sale she had 12 to take back home. How many pastries did she sell?
output: She baked 15 cupcakes and 48 cookies. She took 12 pastries back home. That means she sold 15 + 48 = 63 pastries. The answer is 63.

input: While shopping, Maria bought 35 green towels and 21 white towels. If she gave her mother 34 of them, how many towels did Maria end up with?
output: Maria bought 35 green towels and 21 white towels. She gave her mother 34 towels. She kept the rest. She had initially 35 + 21 = 56 towels. Then she gave away 34. So now she has 56 - 34 = 22 towels. The answer is 22.

input: There were 17 girls and 32 boys trying out for the schools basketball team. If only 10 of them got called back, how many students didn't make the cut?
output: The ones that got called back are the ones that made the cut. So, 10 boys and 10 girls made the cut. The number of students that didn't make the cut is the number of students that didn't get called back. So, 17 - 10 = 7 girls didn't make the cut. The answer is 7 girls.

input: A waiter at 'The Greasy Spoon' restaurant had 39 customers to wait on. During the lunch rush he added another 12 customers. If 49 of the customers didn't leave him a tip, how many customers did leave a tip?
output: 49 is the total number of customers. 39 + 12 = 51. The answer is 51.

input: The school cafeteria ordered 25 red apples and 17 green apples for students lunches. But, if only 10 students wanted fruit, how many extra did the cafeteria end up with?
output: The cafeteria ordered 25 red apples and 17 green apples. If only 10 students wanted fruit, then the rest (25 - 10) red apples and (17 - 10) green apples will be extra. So there are 25 - 10 + 17 - 10 = 12 extra apples in total. The answer is 12. input: At the arcade, Jerry won 29 tickets playing 'whack a mole' and 17 tickets playing 'skee ball'. If he spent 12 of his tickets on a hat, how many tickets does Jerry have left?
output: He won 29 + 17 = 46 tickets playing whack a mole and skee ball. He spent 12 tickets on a hat, so now he has 46 - 12 = 34 tickets left. The answer is 34.

input: Cody had 45 dollars. For his birthday he got 9 more dollars but spent 19 on a new game. How much money does he have now?
output: He had 45 dollars. He got 9 more dollars, so now he has 45 + 9 = 54 dollars. He spent 19 dollars on a new game, so now he has 54 - 19 = $35. The answer is 35.

She distributes  flyers and  buttons to classroom 3. She has  flyers and  buttons left. Continuing this pattern, she distributes flyers to classroom  and buttons to classroom . input: Matthew goes hiking every 12 days and swimming every 6 days. He did both kinds of exercise today. How many days from now will he go both hiking and swimming again?
output: Since he did both today, he won't do both again until 12 + 6 = 18 days later. The answer is 18.

input: Edeena is packing equal numbers of apple slices and grapes for snacks. Edeena bags the apple slices in groups of 18 and the grapes in groups of 9. What is the smallest number of grapes that she can pack?
output: Let the number of apple slices be 'x'. Then the number of grapes be 'y' such that 9x + y = 18x + 9y. Cross multiply and equate the two sides, you get xy = 36x + 27y. Solve for 'y' and you get y = 6. Therefore, the smallest number of grapes that she can pack is 6. input: Ariel is making flower arrangements. He has 7 roses and 14 daisies. If Ariel wants to make all the arrangements identical and have no flowers left over, what is the greatest number of flower arrangements that he can make?
output: This question is asking us to find the least common multiple of 7 and 14. Least common multiple of 7 and 14 is 14, because the only number that is a multiple of both 7 and 14 is 14. input: Sarah's Shipping and Ryan's Mail Services both ship packages. Sarah's trucks will only carry loads of 18 packages. In contrast, Ryan's trucks will only carry loads of 11 packages. If both businesses ended up shipping the same number of packages this morning, what is the minimum number of packages each must have shipped?
output: Let the number of packages Sarah shipped on that day be P and the number of packages Ryan shipped on that day be Q. Then the minimum number of packages that both of them shipped on that day is 18 - 11P + 11Q. If we let M be the minimum number of packages that both of them shipped on that day, then we have 18 - 11P + 11Q = M. Solving for P gives us 11P + 18 - M = 0. Solving for M gives us 11P - 18 + M = 0.  Since both sides are equal to 0, it tells us that as long as 11P - 18 is equal to 0, the equation will have a solution, i.e., there will be a number of packages both of them shipped on that day such that the number of packages Sarah shipped on that day is equal to the number of packages Ryan shipped on that day.  Simplifying, we get P = 18. Thus, the number of packages Sarah shipped on that day is 18, and the number of packages Ryan shipped on that day is 18. The answer is thus 25 packages. input: Nathan is stocking bathrooms at the hotel where he works. He has 18 rolls of toilet paper and 9 bars of soap. If he wants all bathrooms to be stocked identically, with the same combination of supplies in each one and nothing left over, what is the greatest combination of bathrooms Nathan can stock?
output: Nathan can stock 3 bathrooms with soap and 2 bathrooms with toilet paper. Soap is more expensive, so Nathan can't buy more soap than toilet paper. He has 18 rolls of toilet paper, which means he can stock 2 + 18 = 20 bathrooms. He has 9 bars of soap, which means he can stock 3 + 9 = 12 bathrooms. The greatest combination is 20 bathrooms stocked with toilet paper and 12 bathrooms stocked with soap. The answer is 12.

Lastly, since she gave 20 blue flyers to each clothing store owner, there must be 20y total blue flyers. By substituting these values into the original equation, we get xy = 13x + 20y. Solving for x or y will yield the number of red or blue flyers, respectively. input: Aylin is making a scrapbook using 18 photos and 20 newspaper clippings. She wants all the pages to be set up in the same way, with the same combination of photos and newspaper clippings on every page. She also wants to make sure that no items are left over. What is the greatest number of scrapbook pages that Aylin can create?
output: She has 18 photos and 20 newspaper clippings. She wants to use the same combination of photos and newspaper clippings on every page. That means she can make 18 * 20 = 360 pages. The answer is 360.

input: Hay's Linens sells hand towels in sets of 17 and bath towels in sets of 6. If the store sold the same number of each this morning, what is the smallest number of each type of towel that the store must have sold?
output: Let n be the number of hand towels in a set. Let m be the number of bath towels in a set. The store sold n + m towels this morning. The smallest number of hand towels that the store must have sold is 17 - n. The smallest number of bath towels that the store must have sold is 6 - m. The answer is 17 - n - 6 - m.

input: In preparation for a party, Brant is putting desserts onto platters. The chocolate cake is cut into 15 pieces and the cheesecake is cut into 6 pieces. If he wants to prepare identical platters without having any cake left over, what is the greatest number of platters he can prepare?
output: The chocolate cake is cut into 15 pieces. The cheesecake is cut into 6 pieces. If he wants to prepare identical platters without having any cake left over, he must have 15 + 6 = 21 pieces of cake. The answer is 21.

input: Two bikers are riding a circular path. The first rider completes a round in 12 minutes. The second rider completes a round in 18 minutes. If they both started at the same place and time and go in the same direction, after how many minutes will they meet again at the starting point?

input: The radio station gave away a $100 bill for every 100th caller. Every 30th caller received free concert tickets. How many callers must get through before one of them receives both a coupon and a concert ticket?
output: The radio station gave away a $100 bill for every 100th caller. Every 30th caller received free concert tickets. That means that for every 100th caller, there are 30 callers who receive free concert tickets. So, for every 100th caller, there are 100 - 30 = 70 callers who do not receive free concert tickets. So, for every 100th caller, there are 70 callers who receive nothing. So, for every 100th caller, there are 70 callers who receive both a coupon and a concert ticket. The answer is 70.

input: Mrs. Evans has 120 crayons and 30 pieces of paper to give to her students. What is the largest number of students she can have in her class so that each student gets equal number of crayons and equal number of paper?
output: She has 120 crayons and 30 pieces of paper. She wants to give each student equal number of crayons and equal number of paper. So, she must have 120 crayons and 30 pieces of paper divided by the number of students. If she has 10 students, she can give each student 12 crayons and 3 pieces of paper.
